Trump added during the debate that he would release his returns  —   over what he described as his attorney’s objections  —   only after Clinton released roughly 30, 000 emails she had deleted from her private server that she had deemed personal.

”The tax experts consulted by The Times said nothing in the 1995 documents suggested any wrongdoing by Mr Trump, even if the extraordinary size of the loss he declared would have probably attracted extra scrutiny from I R S examiners”.
Former IRS officials have expressed skepticism that anyone would be audited so frequently, and they and other tax experts say there’s no prohibition on Trump releasing his returns even if he is.

The Times report noted that tax experts have found no evidence of wrongdoing connected with Trump’s 1995 tax returns, though the paper claimed that the large loss likely would have drawn the attention of the IRS The newly reported documents are certain to become an issue in the presidential race.
Asked by reporters if he had admitted to not paying federal income taxes, Trump said, ”I didn’t say that at all”.
It also noted that though Trump had paid some taxes, it did not specifically say he had paid income tax.
It goes on to say that Trump has many hundreds of millions in property, sales, and local, state and federal taxes  —   without explicitly mentioning income taxes.
Trump’s income tax history is impossible to verify, because he’s broken a   tradition for   presidential nominees and refused to release his tax returns.

But by refusing to release his tax returns, Trump, who has broken every other rule of politics during his stunning outsider campaign, has been, in effect, betting that he can outlast the demands of opponents who want to make his tax history a pivotal issue in the end game of the campaign.
The Post’s View: What’s Trump hiding by refusing to release his tax returns?

”That being said, Mr Trump has paid hundreds of millions of dollars in property taxes, sales and excise taxes, real estate taxes, city taxes, state taxes, employee taxes and federal taxes, along with very substantial charitable contributions”.
The filings show a net loss of $915, 729, 293 in federal taxable income for the year.
The 1995 tax records obtained by the newspaper show Trump as having reported a $916 million loss on personal income tax returns during that year.
The Times’ report shows Trump that year declared a $916 million loss and lists tax benefits he used after a turbulent financial period for him in the early 1990s.

Under federal law at the time, a declared loss of that size could have allowed Trump to avoid federal taxes for as much as 18 years in a row, according to tax experts interviewed by the newspaper, ”enough to wipe out more than $50 million a year in taxable income” over that stretch of time.

Although he was compliant with the law, it was easy for the Obama campaign to portray him as out of touch with the struggles of everyday Americans who have to pay higher tax rates on lower levels of income.

The opportunity for tax avoidance, which could have shielded as much as $50 million a year in Trump income from any federal income tax liability whatsoever, is the result of rules that permitted him to carry forward net operating losses from his businesses 15 years into the future, and to use those losses to wipe out taxable income for three previous years as well.
The Times said a lawyer for Trump argued that publication of the records would be illegal because Trump had not authorized their disclosure.
Kasowitz reportedly claimed that publishing the documents was illegal because Trump had not authorized the release of any of his returns.
It’s true that none of the report suggests any illegal activity on behalf of Trump.
The impact of the revelations in the Times story were difficult to gauge in their immediate aftermath.
In its story, the Times said the three pages of documents were mailed last month to a Times reporter who had written about Trump’s finances.

Times reporter Susanne Craig, who’s written about the Republican candidate’s business ventures, received three pages of returns via mail from an anonymous source: ”The first page of a New York State resident income tax return, the first page of a New Jersey nonresident tax return and the first page of a Connecticut nonresident tax return”.

WASHINGTON (AP)  —   Donald Trump’s business losses in 1995 were so large that they could have allowed him to avoid paying federal income taxes for as many as 18 years, according to records obtained by The New York Times.

Washington (CNN) Hillary Clinton’s campaign Saturday night seized on a New York Times report about Donald Trump’s 1995 tax records, in which the Times showed he declared a $916 million loss that could have allowed him to legally skip paying federal income taxes for years.

Donald Trump’s campaign is responding to a New York Times report that the real estate mogul claimed hundreds of millions of dollars in losses on tax returns in 1995  —   an amount that could have allowed him to legally avoid paying income taxes for many years.
